Note / decisions: Archival records indicate that sewer infrastructure in lower Manhattan was sparse prior to 1850, and sewer lines constructed before mid 1840s functioned as stormwater drains rather than for household waste. Documentation of early sewer infrastructure is fragmented and not consistently dated. The most comprehensive representation of early sewer distribution identified is "Map 2: Gas Mains and Sewers up to 1838." Although the cholera epidemic occurred in 1832, the limited number of sewer lines in existence at that time and the absence of precise installation dates make it difficult to distinguish which sewers predated the 1832 outbreak. For this reason, sewer presence and density were derived using Map 2: Gas Mains and Sewers up to 1838 cross referenced against Board of Alderman reports and Common Council minutes to confrim sewer existence at ward level.

Source: Moehring, Eugene P. “Map 4 Sewers Installed.” Map. Public Works and the Patterns of Urban Real Estate Growth in Manhattan, 1835-1894. New York: Arno Press, 1981.
Note / decisions: Sewer infrastructure data were limited to lines installed through 1847, despite the 1849 cholera outbreak and the availability of sewer maps spanning 1848-1865. Sewer installations documented after 1847 could not be reliably dated at the individual line level, making it impossible to determine which infrastructure was in place during the 1849 outbreak. Contemporary sources indicate substantial sewer expansion after 1850; including undated post 1847 lines would therefore risk introducing infrastructure that did not exist at the time of the epidemic. To avoid temporal misclassification and contamination of model inputs, only sewer infrastructure verifiably installed by 1847 was used in the 1849 analyses.
